abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Health Project
            for Iraq were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a
            review should be carried out by the Bank as to whether, in
            evaluating emergency projects implemented in countries that
            are in-conflict, a different or modified version of the
            Implementation Completion and Results (ICR) format should be
            developed that will be more suitable. It is important for
            the Bank to 'stay the course' with ongoing
            projects in the face of difficult circumstances, as these
            instruments are a critical means for building country
            knowledge and leveraging future policy dialogue. The Bank
            should always assume low institutional capacity and high
            turnover in a conflict, post-conflict, fragile situation. In
            fragile states, the design of emergency projects in
            conflict-affected situations should be very simple,
            manageable in scope and suitable to context, with a primary
            focus on outputs. In line with the focus on outputs, the
            project development objective (PDO) should also be based on
            outputs only. Safeguard requirements should be simplified
            and the necessary resources should be applied to satisfy
            them. The Bank should support the counterparts in
            establishing monitoring and evolution (M&E) systems and
            methodology in the context of project design, to ensure
            effective oversight of their programs. In situations where
            the project management team is relatively inexperienced,
            Bank support for monitoring outputs may be very valuable to
            project management. A Master Implementation Manual (MIM) and
            a Project Implementation Manual (PIM) that provide a clear
            definition of implementation procedures are important
            elements for successful projects.

10227429.trustfund:
TF054322-IRTF-IQ EMERGENCY HEALTH
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF054404-IRTF-IQ EMERGENCY HEALTH
            REHABILITATION PROJECT (RECIPIENT EXECUTED)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Health Rehabilitation
            Project for Iraq aims to improve access to quality emergency
            services in selected health facilities to serve the urgent
            needs of the Iraqi population. There are four project
            components. 1) Rehabilitation of priority emergency
            services, including emergency obstetric care in 12 selected
            hospitals, and the urgent provision of basic medical and
            laboratory equipment to the selected rehabilitated
            hospitals. 2) Provision of a 3 to 6 month supply of up to 37
            essential emergency drugs to be used at emergency facilities
            rehabilitated through this project. 3) Continued support to
            strengthening of planning and management capacity within the
            central and Governorate health administrations. 4) Support
            to project management.

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Emergency Health Rehabilitation
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This Environmental and Social Screening
            and Assessment Framework (ESSAF) provides general policies,
            guidelines, codes of practice and procedures to be
            integrated into the implementation of the initial phase of
            Bank-supported emergency reconstruction operations in Iraq.
            This Framework has been developed to ensure compliance with
            the Bank's safeguard policies, under the current
            conditions in Iraq. The objective of the ESSAF is to ensure
            that activities under the proposed reconstruction operations
            will address the following issues: protect human health;
            prevent or compensate any loss of livelihood; minimize
            environmental degradation as a result of either individual
            subprojects, or their cumulative effects; minimize impacts
            on cultural property; and, enhance positive environmental
            and social outcomes. Project design, and subproject
            selection will aim at maintaining regional balance, and
            equity among ethnic religious groups, considering variations
            in population density. Employment opportunities within the
            projects will be available on an equal basis to all, on the
            basis of professional competence, irrespective of gender, or
            ethnic or religious group. In all projects which require
            consultations with local communities, or beneficiaries,
            consultations will be conducted to elicit the views of the
            male, and female population. The safeguard screening and
            mitigation process will include: a list of negative impacts
            rendering a proposed subproject ineligible for support; a
            proposed checklist of likely environment and social impacts
            to be filled out for each subproject or group of
            subprojects; guidelines for land and asset acquisition,
            entitlements and compensation; procedures for the protection
            of cultural property, including the chance discovery of
            archaeological artifacts, unrecorded graveyards and burial
            sites; relevant elements of the codes of practice for the
            prevention, and mitigation of potential environmental
            impacts; and, a sample of Environmental Safeguards
            procedures for inclusion in the Technical Specifications of
            Contracts. Checklists for subproject approval, and the
            process format are included. Some of the mitigation measures
            are addressed as follows: prioritize leak detection and
            repair of pipe networks, to minimize water contamination,
            and conduct chemical and bacteriological testing of water
            quality from adjacent comparable sources, prior to
            installation of new sources, and a redesign should be
            conducted to prevent contamination if sources are found
            contaminated. Followed by subsequent monitoring. Night-soil
            latrines, or septic tanks should be sealed, with outflows
            drainage flows located at least 10m from water sources, or
            be connected to a working drain. Community participation and
            organization should be ensured for effective planning, and
            management of infrastructure, while downstream water users
            (e.g. water supply, irrigation, livestock watering) should
            be included in planning of water storage reservoirs.
            Procedures regarding archaeological finds should be
            coordinated with the appropriate agencies.
